passages.text: Equity ResearchAugust 28,2025
EQB 3Q25 Earnings Review: Credit Headwinds Continue - Downgrade Hold

Out of necessity, EQB is undergoing a major re-haul of its executive talent at a point where it is facing significant operational headwinds. While its business model is far from broken, we do not expect to see any immediate solutions to the pressures it currently faces. As a result, we believe that its valuation will be compressed until the rough patch eases, and we recommend sitting on the sidelines. Consequently, we are reducing our rating to Hold from Buy.

**Credit** **headwinds** **shift** **from** **commercial** **to** **consumer.** Although the pressures were different,EQB's third quarter miss mirrors its disappointing results from the second quarter. Provisions for credit loses remain a headwind, but although commercial stabilized, it was its personal lending portfolio that exhibited weakness in the quarter. Further, while loan volumes remained strong, net interest margins were negatively impacted by lower rates on loans, while funding costs remained much stickier.

In conjunction with the earnings release, on top of Chadwick Westlake just starting as CEO, EQB announced that it has hired Anilisa Sainani as SVP and Chief Financial Officer. Ms Sainani comes from RBC, where she held various senior roles, including as VP, Chief Accountant, and, most recently, Chief Operating Officer, CFO Group. David Wilkes, currently VP and Head of Finance and filling in on the CFO duties, will assume the new role of SVP and Chief Strategy & Growth Officer.

**How** **does** **this** **change** **our** **thesis?** We view the current pressure on growth and profitability as largely transitory as EQB's business model and platform remains a compelling proposition.However, the dual headwinds of a challenging macro environment as well as a significant transition in its management team implies that rectifying the several issues impacting EQB in the quarter may take some time.

**Where** **do** **we** **go** **from** **here?** It appears that EQB is continuing to sacrifice its net interest margins via maintaining high interest savings rates to attract core customers at the cost of near term net interest margins. While we believe that this is likely a winning strategy over the longer term, the immediate impact on profitability in context of heightened credit costs is jarring. Further, post the unexpected passing of its former CEO, EQB is dealing with new (and not so new) members on its executive committee.

While we view the franchise as being far from broken, immediate resolution of its current difficulties are less likely until the new team gets its feet underneath themselves. Consequently, we are reducing our rating to a Hold, commensurate with the $12 reduction in our target price to $107 and a reduction in our target multiple reflecting the current credit challenges. That said, should we see a resumption of growth and profitability early in 2026, it would not be beneath us to reconsider our rating once again as we have faith in the platform and management, once it is able to stabilize the business.

Please see analyst certifications, important disclosure information, and information regarding the status of non-US analysts on pages 7-12 of this report. * Jefferies Securities, Inc. ^ Jefferies LLC / Jefferies Research Services, LLC

We view the current pressure on growth and profitability (mid- 2025), largely transitory, as EQB's business model and platform remains a compelling proposition. That said, the dual headwinds of a challenging macro environment as well as a significant transition in its management team implies that rectifying the several issues impacting EQB may take some time.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View
Our base- case price target of C\$107 for EQB is based on an 8.5x forward P/E against FY26E EPS of \$12.64.
Upside Scenario, C\$118, \(+16\%\)

An improving Canadian economy generates better than expected growth and performance by the bank's residential lending portfolio, as our upside scenario of C\$118 for EQB is based on a \(10\%\) increase in FY26E EPS vs a forward P/E of 8.5x.
Downside Scenario, C\$80, \(- 21\%\)
Weighed by weaker than expected economic growth, our downside scenario of C\$80 for EQB, is based on a \(10\%\) decline to its FY26E EPS, against a forward P/E of 7.0x.
1) Climate: Within its climate strategy, the bank considers emissions, risks, governance, and products and services.
2) Customers: Provide a best-in-class customer experience and products that serve this purpose.

3) Community: EQB believes it owes a duty of care to the communities that house its employees, customers, business partners, and shareholders and seeks to support these communities with positive actions.
4) Controls: The bank puts its business with a prudent risk appetite and never wavers from ethical behavior.
1) Integrate climate-related metrics and targets into executive compensation.
2) Target the underlying underperformed businesses who would benefit from having access to greater banking services at low or no fees.
3) Women to represent at least \(30\%\) of its independent directors.

1) How does ESG align and support EQB's medium-term objectives?  
2) Does EQB envision a time when the pursuit of ESG initiatives is incongruent with creating shareholder value?

Against the backdrop of a soft landing and lower interest rates, fueling improved consumer sentiment and stronger housing market, could translate into better than expected performance for EQB's residential related lending portfolios.
Third Quarter Results: Negative

Earnings quality. Overall, earnings quality was a bit mixed. While EQB earned through higher provisions; however, this was offset by higher securitization fees. Overall, in our opinion, the quality of earnings was lower than it has generated in the past.
Operating leverage/performance: A simple decline in sequential core revenues with an increase in expenses generated negative operating leverage that eroded profitability in the quarter.
Risk: EQB maintains a strong capital ratio, but recent quarters have highlighted heightened credit risk.
Q3-25 Earnings per Share Overview(in C$ 000s)Pre-taxAfter-taxEPSvs. Q2-25vs. Q3-24Reported$101,207$73,364$1.90(14.3%)(33.2%)Adjustments:Net adjustments$0.17
Core$79,678$2.07(10.3%)(30.1%)vs. JEF - Above/(Below)$2.77(25.3%)vs. Consensus - Above/(Below)$2.53(18.2%)
Source: Company data, Jefferies estimates, Factset

EQB reported adjusted EPS of \(\) 2.07\(, well below consensus of\) \ \(2.53\) and our forecast of \(\) 2.77\(. Against expectations, higher provisions and lower net interest income were the culprits on the miss. Provisions for credits losses of\) \ \(34MM\) were well above consensus' expectations of \(\) 27MM\(, fueled by higher personal provisions, as EQB felt the weakening macro impact. Somewhat ironically, commercial provisions held in sequentially and its equipment financing provisions were down slightly.

On the credit front, gross impaired loans were up almost \(\) 140MM\(\) (5.2\%)\(in the quarter, with increases experienced across all broad categories. Although it appears that equipment finance is stabilizing, there was a modest uptick in commercial, but the bulk of the growth came within its consumer portfolios. Net impaired loans as a percentage of the portfolio increased by\) 8bps to 1.64\%\(after a 9bps increase in the second quarter), and the PCL ratio came in at 0.28% (up from 0.25% in Q2 but still below the recent high of\) 0.40\%\(in Q4 - 24).

Despite the deterioration in credit quality, loans under management were up 3.3% sequentially and 10% from a year ago. That said, on balance sheet loans remained essentially flat (and below expectations) as EQB continues to securitize its multi- unit residential mortgages in pursuit of NIR, which did come in well ahead of expectations.
On returning capital to shareholders, EQB announced a 3.8% increase in its quarterly dividend to \(\) 0.55\(representing a pro forma dividend yield of 2.2\%\$
Parsing through the quarter's results, we highlight the following key profitability metrics:

Net interest income: On an adjusted basis, NII fell by \(\) 17\(million (or - 6.3\% Q / Q), coming in at\) \ \(254.1\) million. The lower NII was weighed by weaker net interest margins (- 25 bps Q/Q), was primarily attributed to the pact of attrition of higher margin loans, an increase in the average cost of EQ Bank demand deposits, an increase in liquidity portfolio, and in- period impacts of derivatives related to hedging interest rate risk.

- Non-interest revenues: NIR rose by \(11.2 million (or +25\% Q/Q)\), coming in at \(56.1 million, largely driven by ongoing contributions from EQB's fee-based businesses, and gains from securitization associated with its multi-unit residential business.- Non-interest expenses: On an adjusted basis, NIX jumped by \(9.7 million (or +6.2\%)\), coming in at \)165.6 million, weighed by ongoing investments in technology, innovation, and capabilities; higher product and operation costs associated with a growing EQ Bank customer base, and an increase in premises costs.
Third Quarter Results: Negative
Figure 2 - EQB - Credit Summary (in C$ thousands)

- On an adjusted (and reported) basis, credit quality continued to weaken, as total provisions for credit losses remained elevated, coming in at \(34 million vs. the Street's forecast of \)27.0 million and our forecast of \)16.4 million. On a relative basis, the PCL ratio edged up 3 bps to 0.28%.
- The increase in provisions largely reflected higher provisions in Personal (+36.3% Q/Q) and Commercial Lending (+14.9% Q/Q), while credit losses in Equipment Financing declined, down -8.8% Q/Q.

- Parsing the credit losses, Stage 1 and 2 PCLs climbed by more than three-quarters from last quarter, coming in at \(10.0 million, while Stage 3 provisions held steady but still elevated, settling at \)23.0 million vs. \(23.3 million last quarter.

- On the gross impaired loans front, GILs came in at $815.3 million, climbing over 5% sequentially and up roughly 44% from a year ago. The higher GILs were primarily driven by increases in Personal, excluding consumer lending (+9.5% Q/Q); while Commercial, excluding equipment financing (+2.2% Q/Q) also edged higher. On a relative basis, we estimate GIL ratio rose to 1.73% vs 1.66% last quarter.
Figure 3 - EQB - Gross Impaired Loans (in C$ thousands)
Source: Company reports, Jefferies
Figure 4 - EQB - Allowance for Credit Losses (in C$ thousands)
Source: Company reports, Jefferies
Figure 5 - EQB - Net Formations (in C\$ thousands)
Source: Company reports, Jefferies
Figure 6 - EQB - Provisions for Credit Losses (in C\$ thousands)
Source: Company reports, Jefferies
Third Quarter Results: Positive
Figure 7 - EQB - Capital Summary (in C\$ thousands)
Source: Company reports, Jefferies

After three consecutive quarters of declines, EQB's Common Equity Tier 1 ratio strengthened in Q3, edging up 10 bps to \(13.3\%\) , primarily reflecting solid internal capital generation, as well as a slower pace of risk weighted asset growth.
In conjunction with Q3 earnings, EQB announced a dividend hike of \(3.8\%\) in its quarterly dividend per share to \(0.55\) , increasing its dividend yield by approximately 10 bps to \(2.2\%\) .

Although EQB repurchased 292,617 common shares during the nine months ending July 31, the bank repurchased nil shares during the third quarter. In January, the bank renewed its normal course issuer bid program to repurchase 2.3 million common shares, representing \(8.4\%\) of its public float.

EQB's struggle with heightened provisions and the headwinds it faces on net interest income results in a decrease to our forecasts (as illustrated in Figure 8 below). While we do believe that much of the pressures should be resolved over the medium term, we have reassessed our outlook for earnings, with the result that lower margins, higher credit costs and a decline in efficiency results in lower than previously anticipated run- rate earnings. Coming out of the quarter, we are lowering our target price to \(\) 107\(from\) \ \(119\) , reflecting the reduction in our 2026 EPS forecast as well as a 0.5x reduction in our target multiple to 8.5x.
Figure 8 - EQB - EPS Summary
Source: Company reports, Jefferies
Figure 9-EQB-Income Statement
Source: Company reports, Jefferies
Equitable BankEQB operates as a holding company, and provides residential lending, commercial lending, and saving solutions through its wholly owned subsidiary Equitable Bank.
Our base case price target of C\$107 for EQB is based on an 8.5x forward P/E against FY26E EPS of \$12.64.
Risks to our investment thesis and valuation include:
- Credit issues related to its commercial lending portfolio continues to persist, resulting in continued volatility in provisions for credit losses and weighing on the bottom line.

- On the macro front, a more depressed economic slowdown weighs on credit, lending volumes, and non-interest revenue lines, including residential mortgage lending, equipment financing, and decumulation loans.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period. NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
- EQB Inc (EQB CN: CS101.65, HOLD)
